all_paragraphs: “Social distancing” has become very popular these days but it is not always obvious how the rules can fit our daily life. In this story, we are going to study a social distancing problem and find solution to it using Genetic Algorithms. After setting the problem and its constraints, I’ll summarize the principles of Genetic Algorithms (GA) before applying these principles to our problem.

This summer (August 2020), people from Neo4j (the graph database) proposed weekly challenges to be solved with graphs. The advanced barbecue challenges of week 1 comprises a social distancing task, whose rules where the following:

While this problem can be solved with graphs (see the proposed solution here: https://medium.com/neo4j/summer-of-nodes-week-1-the-barbecue-ead98d441a91), it sounds to me like a constraint problem that can be addressed with other techniques. In this post, I investigate the use of GA to solve this specific problem.
Talking about GA, let’s focus on the main principles behind this technique and how this kind of algorithms can help solving the above problem.

Contrarily to the common approaches, GA does not consider a single solution and update it depending on some conditions (gradient….). Instead, GA will consider a population of solutions, and evolve them over several generations based on a selection process biased towards the “best” individuals. Now that we have a representation for each solution, let’s define its fitness, i.e. its “closeness” to an satisfactory solution.

To define fitness, we have to take into account each of the three constraints defined in the problem definition section, plus the fact that each seat must be assigned only once. Each time a constraint is violated, the fitness will be increased accordingly.

Here we go, we have solved a social distancing problem using the power of Genetic Algorithms. You will be able to meet your friends at a barbecue while limiting the risks related to Covid-19!

You can download this code and try and modify the parameters and see how the solver behaves. Both the input parameters (guests, number of tables…), and the model parameters (size of the population, probability of mutation, type of cross over…) can be changed.
